ANZ (ANZ AT)

Basic Materials / Energy

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said China will not be ripping the US anymore and doubts China trade talks will be successful. (Newswires)


UK

UK Cabinet agreed a Brexit customs 'backstop' option with the new customs proposal to prevent a hard border in Ireland.
Reports stated that ministers signed off on the "backstop" that would see the UK match EU tariffs after 2020 if there is no deal on their preferred customs arrangements, while the measure offers the guarantee sought by the Irish government to stop a hard border being introduced at the end of the transition period. (BBC)

EU is to brush off UK PM May’s pitch for customs plan guarantees, while there were also reports that UK established a ministerial team to deal with border disruptions after Brexit. (Newswires)

A source at PM May's office dismissed Telegraph reports of remaining in the customs union beyond 2021. (Newswires)


EU

US President Trump said the EU has been terrible to the US on trade and reportedly told German Chancellor Merkel to drop support for a major gas deal with Russia and instead buy American gas instead to avoid a trade war, while White House economic adviser Hasset is also said to see no trade war if Germany invests. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker said the EU wants unlimited exemption from US tariffs and adds the EU is ready to discuss WTO reforms with the US. (Newswires)


FX

Mexico’s Central Bank kept rates unchanged at 7.50% as expected, via unanimous decision. (Newswires)

Hong Kong Monetary Authority purchased HKD 1.96bln to keep HKD in trading band. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said he had discussions with IEA’s Birol to underscore commitment to maintaining stability in the oil market. Furthermore, there were also reports that Saudi Arabia & UAE oil ministers spoke about oil prices and said they are both concerned about recent market volatility, while they both also see ample supply of oil and agree oil prices are being driven by geopolitical tensions. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said US and North Korea are continuing to prepare for a summit next month and warned that if North Korea doesn’t make a deal they would most likely put in place a ‘Libya model’ which he referred to as a total decimation, but also stated that he thinks North Korea leader Kim would be very happy if they reached a deal. (Guardian) In separate news, the White House said the US has no intention of altering military exercises with South Korea. (Newswires)

There were later reports that North Korea is to increase efforts to defuse military tensions, according to state media. (KCNA)
 

US

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) does not see the US economy entering a recession and forecasts growth between 2.5% and 2.75%. Kaplan also stated that the US economy is either at or past full employment, while he added that he is concerned that there will be no capacity in the US for fiscal stimulus in the next recession. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said low wage growth is a big conundrum and noted a theory that there is more slack in the labour market. (Newswires)

Canada’s PM Trudeau declined to comment when asked whether a NAFTA deal can be sealed this year but stated that current auto proposals are broadly acceptable to industries in the three nations, while Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau is optimistic a NAFTA deal can be completed and thinks the NAFTA sunset clause is not practical. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US equity futures were rangebound after Wednesday’s close, however, at the US cash open, ES caught a bid and extended towards the key 2732.50 resistance before paring back the gains and sliding to lows as the session progressed. In later trade, US President Trump said he doubts trade talks will be successful with China, which provided bears with a catalyst to drive the emini to lows around 2710, but those knee-jerk losses were pared back, and the Emini once again consolidated around 2720. In stock specifics, Thursday’s trade saw the unofficial end of earnings season as Wal-Mart (WMT) reported its numbers which slightly beat estimates, however, the retail giant did close lower and was one of the big underperformers in the DJI; Cisco (CSCO) also reported earnings which were relatively in line with estimates, but its operating income was lower. In the pre-market, Alphabet’s (GOOGL) YouTube announced it is to start a music subscription service which put pressure on Spotify Tech, (SPOT) and Pandora (P). Energy names outperformed on Thursday, as Morgan Stanley raised its US refining and marketing industry forecast, which saw the SPX leaders dominated by energy names, (MRO, ANDV & VLO). SPX -0.08% at 2720, NDX -0.4% at 6901, DJI -0.22% at 24715.

The Treasury curve steepened marginally, despite slightly softer volumes when compared to mid-week trade, and the ranges weren’t exactly wide on Thursday. Yields continued to rise to fresh highs along the cruve, except for in the 2yr sector, where they were slightly lower. Most of the action concentrated in the long-end of the curve, where 10yr yields were higher by c.1bps and 30yr by c.3bps at settlement. 2s30s widened by c.5bps, 2s10s and 5s30s by c.3bps. Today’s USD 11bln in 10yr TIPS auction tailed by 1bps, bid-to-cover came in at 2.42x in line with the 6-auction average though dealer participation was well above average. The Treasury announced next week’s supply of USD 48bln in 3-month bills, USD 42bln in 6-month bills and USD 26bln 52-week bills next. It will also auction USD 16bln in a 2-year FRN reopening, USD 30bln in 7-year notes, USD 36bln in 5-year notes and USD 33bln in 2-year notes. Of note, the Treasury finally introduced a two-month bill. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled one tick lower at 118-16+.

US MARKET WRAP 17 May 2018: Trump wary on China, NAFTA soft deadline saw no deal, Banxico unchanged, yields remain at recent highs
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries mostly lower, DXY flat, Crude flat.
* REAR-VIEW: Trump tough talk on trade, NAFTA; Banxico on hold; lots of central bank speak.

* AHEAD: Japan CPI overnight; Canada CPI and retail sales on Friday; Fedpseak on Friday (voter Mester, voter Brainard, non-voter Kaplan again), S&P on Netherlands and S&P on Switzerland.

 

*NAFTA: The three members failed to make a deal by the soft deadline imposed by Paul Ryan last week. Mexican Foreign Minister Videgaray said NAFTA talks are continuing and a deal will be reached when conditions are right, emphasising that there is no ‘final deadline’. On the flip side, Canada’s PM Trudeau declined to comment on whether a NAFTA deal can be sealed this year, arguing that current auto proposals are broadly acceptable to industries in the three nations. Canada’s Finance Minister Morneau was more optimistic: although he conceded that a sunset clause is not practical, though he said he was confident of reaching a deal.  

* TRADE: US President Trump said be doubted that the trade talks with China will be successful, emphasizing that China will not be ripping the US anymore. Separately, he reportedly told Germany's Merkel to replace American gas and drop support for a major gas deal with Russia and defined the US- NATO relationship is very good. Elsewhere, US Trade Advisor Navarro was said to not be attending the China trade talks. This confirmed yesterday’s reports, which also suggested he will be one of the principles. Note Navarro is a notorious China hawk, having been critical on China in the past and this came.

*GEOPOLITICAL: At first, US President Trump appeared sanguine about the possibility of not meeting North Korea’s Kim for talks, but in other comments, threatened the nation, saying that he will decimate North Korea like Libya if Kim Jong Un does not make a deal. Separately, the White House is proceeding with preparations for a summit with Kim, adding nothing has changed on its end. The White House also toed the Pentagon’s line that there is no discussion of scaling back US-South Korea military exercises. Separately, US President Trump said the US-NATO relationship is very good.

*MEXICO CENTRAL BANK: Banxico kept interest rates unchanged at 7.50%, as expected – a unanimous decision –as inflation continues to cool. The central bank noted risks to inflation are to the upside, while risks to growth are to the downside. Analysts expect Banxico to move in step with the FOMC after the June meeting, where the Fed is expected to raise rates.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said low wage growth is a big conundrum, and suggested that one theory why this may be the case is that there is more slack in the labour market. Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) stated he does not see the US economy entering a recession, with growth likely to stand between 2.5% and 2.75%. He also said the US economy is either at or past full employment.

*ECB SPEAK: ECB's Constancio (Dovish) In an event marking his departure as ECB vice chair, Constancio said the ECB has to monitor bond yields in Italy, adding the ECB is also concerned with FX volatility. He warned there must be acceptance the ECB has no excuses not to intervene in the sovereign bond market to deal with acute liquidity stress.

*DATA: The US Leading Index rose to 0.4% in April, sending positive signals for growth which may likely to persist in Q2, analysts says. The interest rate spread remains a key component in the index, even though the yield curve has flattened recently, Wells Fargo’s analysts note. The only negative components for this reading were stock prices and housing permits. Wells remains positive on growth despite the moderation in the index seen in the last six months. US Initial Jobless Claims ticked higher last week, to 222k from 211k and modestly above the 215k consensus. Analysts at Pantheon noted this reading may come as a correction following the previous three-weeks figures which remained in the 209k-211k bracket. The US labour market remains in close proximity to the full-employment level and the latest data seems to indicate that wage growth will pick up in H218, Pantheon said. The Philly Fed beat the consensus at 21 and moved higher to 34.4 in May from 23.2 in April. This month’s print was the highest since May 2017, mostly supported by new orders, which were highest since March 1973, and partially by a rise in shipments and employment. Pantheon notes the rise in new orders is unlikely to be a sustained one, though this month’s encouraging results open some hope for a rebound in the ISM Index.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.08% at 2720, NDX -0.4% at 6901, DJI -0.22% at 24715.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.33%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.03%, Energy: +1.43%, Financials: -0.30%, Health Care: -0.10%, Industrials: +0.29%, Materials: +0.17%

US equity futures were rangebound after Wednesday’s close, however, at the US cash open, ES caught a bid and extended towards the key 2732.50 resistance before paring back the gains and sliding to lows as the session progressed. In later trade, US President Trump said he doubts trade talks will be successful with China, which provided bears with a catalyst to drive the emini to lows around 2710, but those knee-jerk losses were pared back, and the Emini once again consolidated around 2720.

In stock specifics, Thursday’s trade saw the unofficial end of earnings season as Wal-Mart (WMT) reported its numbers which slightly beat estimates, however, the retail giant did close lower and was one of the big underperformers in the DJI; Cisco (CSCO) also reported earnings which were relatively in line with estimates, but its operating income was lower. In the pre-market, Alphabet’s (GOOGL) YouTube announced it is to start a music subscription service which put pressure on Spotify Tech, (SPOT) and Pandora (P).

In sectors, energy names outperformed on Thursday, as Morgan Stanley raised its US refining and marketing industry forecast, which saw the SPX leaders dominated by energy names, (MRO, ANDV & VLO).

The latest on CBS (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) saw CBS lose its first attempt to dilute Shari Redstone’s voting power in order to scupper a merger between the two names, with a Delaware Judge ruled against it. CBS followed with a statement saying it remains fully committed to protecting shareholder interests, and mentioned the ruling allows further legal challenges if they deem National Amusements actions as unlawful.

*CRUDE: WTI Crude futures settle unchanged at $71.49/bbl; Brent crude futures settle higher by 2 cents at $79.30/bbl. It was a choppy session for crude, but futures are consolidating around recent levels, ultimately little changed on the day, influenced by action in the USD, and pre-settlement, seemingly falling in sympathy with equities on a headline that Trump doubts that trade talks with China will be successful. Elsewhere, in a joint statement, Saudi Arabia and UAE oil ministers said they are both concerned about recent market volatility, but they both see ample supply of oil, and agreed that oil prices are being driven by geopolitical tensions – comments that were in line with the sources stories earlier in the week. The UEA energy minister himself suggested that there are bigger issues to be concerned about than the Iran nuclear deal, pointing to declining production in Venezuela as an example. Separately, JODI reported that Saudi crude exports declined to 7.1mln BPD in March. In Africa, Shipments of Nigerian Bonny Light crude oil were seeing loading delays, according to sources; later in the day, it was reported that Nigeria cut the premium for Bonny and Qua Iboe crude to $0.69 and $0.70/bbl respectively. And finally, there has been a lot of analyst chatter on crude today, with the folks at Goldman Sachs said that the current fundamental backdrop for oil is more bullish than they had expected, adding that by Q1 2019, markets are likely to remain in deficit, and inventories would draw to critical operating levels if actions are not taken by OPEC and Russia. The folks at Barclays raised their Brent oil price assumption to $73/bbl in 2018 and $70/bbl in 2019.

*TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled one tick lower at 118-16+. The Treasury curve steepened marginally, despite slightly softer volumes when compared to mid-week trade, and the ranges weren’t exactly wide on Thursday. Yields continued to rise to fresh highs along the cruve, except for in the 2yr sector, where they were slightly lower. Most of the action concentrated in the long-end of the curve, where 10yr yields were higher by c.1bps and 30yr by c.3bps at settlement. 2s30s widened by c.5bps, 2s10s and 5s30s by c.3bps. Today’s USD 11bln in 10yr TIPS auction tailed by 1bps, bid-to-cover came in at 2.42x in line with the 6-auction average though dealer participation was well above average. The Treasury announced next week’s supply of USD 48bln in 3-month bills, USD 42bln in 6-month bills and USD 26bln 52-week bills next. It will also auction USD 16bln in a 2-year FRN reopening, USD 30bln in 7-year notes, USD 36bln in 5-year notes and USD 33bln in 2-year notes. Of note, the Treasury finally introduced a two-month bill.

*FOREX: DXY: A minor topside range extension for the Dollar index, largely due to ongoing weakness or retracements in G10 currency rivals. The DXY nudged back up above 93.550, but remained hampered by niggling trade, tariff and protectionism concerns, although the Greenback displayed more resilience and resolve in the face of the latest bout of EM intervention.

EUR, GBP: The single currency and Sterling have both been volatile amidst breaking headlines on events in Rome and Brexit, with EURUSD straddling 1.1800 and Cable trading just above 1.3500, while EURGBP held mostly below 0.8750. In short, Italy’s 5-Star and League parties are still working out some coalition issues and are yet to decide on the PM and other prominent Government positions, while the UK appears to be considering a customs union back-stop even if media speculation about staying in the current EU framework beyond 2021 is not an option.  

JPY: An underperformer all day, as USDJPY picked its way through export and option supply at 110.50 then corporate offers said to be sitting at 110.60, 110.70 and at least some at 110.80. The next layer lies in wait at 110.90, but chart resistance at the 110.85 Fib has capped the headline pair, thus far.

NZD, AUD: The Kiwi has also lagged major counterparts and its antipodean peer, with NZDUSD unable to sustain 0.6900+ levels even though the latest NZ budget was fundamentally supportive, as AUDNZD climbed above 1.0900 and AUDUSD maintained 0.7500+ status.

CAD, CHF: The Loonie failed to derive much fuel from the latest crude price rally as time runs out for a NAFTA deal by COB and latest Mexican comments suggest more chance of an agreement by the end of May – USDCAD just below 1.2800 from around 1.2750, also shrugging a decent Canadian ADP survey on the basis that official jobs data came out last week, USDMXN around 19.7000. Meanwhile, USDCHF rebounded from sub-par territory to probe 1.0030 peaks.

PRIMER: Mexico Central Bank will publish rate decision at 1900 BST/1400 EDT, expected to hold at 7.50%
content:
• TD Securities says MXN is suffering from the impact of rising US yields and a broad USD rally against EM. Losses have been exacerbated by inadequate liquidity conditions.
  • “We do not think there should be any expectation that Banxico would respond to current market volatility with an interest rate hike. As a result, an on-hold decision should be MXN neutral,” TD says, “we would be concerned if Banxico were to respond with a hike given that it is highly unjustified at the current juncture. A hike may send the wrong signal to markets, thus reducing policy flexibility in the future.”
  • TD believes that Banxico should continue to sound hawkish. “Policymakers may even voice increased concerns about the potential inflationary impact of current exchange rate volatility as it relates to elevated inflation expectations and pass- through.” However, TD notes that volatility has already impacted rates pricing by moving the TIIE curve higher. “Accordingly, it is unlikely that Banxico rhetoric would significantly change pricing even if policy makers acknowledge that another rate hike may be necessary at some point.”

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Eur/Usd roams around 1.1800 and Pound pivots 1.3500 vs Usd
content:
DXY

A minor topside range extension for the Dollar index, largely due to ongoing weakness or retracements in G10 currency rivals. The DXY nudged back up above 93.550, but remained hampered by niggling trade, tariff and protectionism concerns, although the Greenback displayed more resilience and resolve in the face of the latest bout of EM intervention.

EUR/GBP

The single currency and Sterling have both been volatile amidst breaking headlines on events in Rome and Brexit, with Eur/Usd straddling 1.1800 and Cable trading either side of 1.3500, while Eur/Gbp held mostly below 0.8750. In short, Italy’s 5-Star and League parties are still working out some coalition issues and are yet to decide on the PM and other prominent Government positions, while the UK appears to be considering a customs union back-stop even if media speculation about staying in the current EU framework beyond 2021 is not an option.   

JPY    

An underperformer all day, as Usd/Jpy picked its way through export and option supply at 110.50 then corporate offers said to be sitting at 110.60, 110.70 and at least some at 110.80. The next layer lies in wait at 110.90, but chart resistance at the 110.85 Fib has capped the headline pair, thus far.

NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has also lagged major counterparts and its antipodean peer, with Nzd/Usd unable to sustain 0.6900+ levels even though the latest NZ budget was fundamentally supportive, as Aud/Nzd climbed above 1.0900 and Aud/Usd maintained 0.7500+ status. The Aud gleaned more (in the end) from overnight labour data, but did get close to hefty option expiries at 0.7500 ahead of the NY cut.

CAD/CHF  

The Loonie failed to derive much fuel from the latest crude price rally as time runs out for a NAFTA deal by COB and latest Mexican comments suggest more chance of an agreement by the end of May – Usd/Cad up to 1.2800 from around 1.2750, also shrugging a decent Canadian ADP survey on the basis that official jobs data came out last week, Usd/Mxn around 19.7000. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf rebounded from sub-par territory to probe 1.0030 peaks.

Barclays comments on CBS (CBS)/Viacom (VIAB) upcoming court hearing
content: 'While the eventual outcome of the litigation between CBS and controlling parent National Amusement (NAI) remains unclear, it might be uncharacteristic of the court to permit the CBS board to dilute NAI’s controlling stake (just for the purpose of preventing a Viacom merger) – the precedence for which certainly is not obvious to us. We, however, will not be surprised to see the court try and ring fence CBS’ board from NAI’s direct involvement in strategic decision making, which lowers the probability of a CBS-Viacom merger (although not to zero, given the two companies’ boards had seemingly agreed upon the economics of a merger and any disagreement seems to have been focused on the leadership of the combined company, which can still likely be resolved). We think the decision on the stock dividend at tomorrow’s CBS board meeting still faces a high hurdle, as a) the judge might not allow for the vote to take place, b) if the vote does take place, the two independent directors that were not part of the CBS complaint might not vote in favor of the proposal, c) potentially such a decision might now require a 90% super-majority of the board, assuming today’s by-law changes are not struck down by the court.  For CBS bond investors, we think there seems to be little potential upside in most of the scenarios, even as potential outcomes for Viacom investors can be more extreme, but may still be skewed to the upside for the long-end bondholders (as the risk to an immediate downgrade of Viacom to high yield by S&P is likely low, given Viacom management’s commitment to investment grade ratings and the uncertainty around potential strategic outcomes)'.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European bourses mostly higher as markets await further updates from Italy’s populist parties
  • US Treasury yields underpins the Greenback and offers protection against global tariff headwinds
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, ECB’s Constancio, Fed’s Kashkari, Kaplan and BoE’s Haldane

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued as the initial tailwind from a rebound in US stocks gradually waned after trade protectionism concerns were stoked overnight. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) both opened higher as they took cue from Wall St where markets shrugged off rising Treasury yields and US data including Industrial Production provided some encouragement. However, Australian stocks then retreated amid heavy losses in the Industrials sector and a deterioration in both Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) and Hang Seng (-0.5%) in which the latter wiped out gains of over 1%. This was due to trade concerns after China’s Mofcom released its statement on previously announced tariffs in which it is to levy reciprocal taxes on some US products and halt tariff concessions on imports of US fruit and pork, which doesn’t bode well ahead of today’s US-China trade talks. Furthermore, Japan was also said to inform the WTO regarding its own trade response and that it is ready to retaliate against US tariff actions, although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later downplayed it and stated that nothing yet has been decided. Conversely, not all was not all was gloomy in the region as Tencent outperformed in Hong Kong with gains nearly 5% after it posted an over 60% increase in Q1 net. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as yields played catch up to their US counterparts, while a 5yr JGB auction also failed to support as the b/c and accepted prices slipped from prior.

China is to levy reciprocal tax on some US products and will stop tariff concessions on imports of US fruits and pork, according to statement posted by China Mofcom regarding previously announced tariffs, although Mofcom also reiterated China doesn't want to see trade tensions with US to escalate. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3679 (Prev. 6.3745).

There were reports that Japan is said to inform WTO regarding retaliatory steps related to US tariffs and will also notify WTO it is prepared to retaliate against US tariff actions. However, Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later answered a question on retaliatory measures on US tariffs, in which he stated Japan is considering steps under WTO framework but nothing has been decided yet. (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders (Mar) M/M -3.9% vs. Exp. -3.0% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders (Mar) Y/Y -2.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 2.4%)

Australian Employment Change (Apr) 22.6k vs. Exp. 20.0k (Prev. 4.9k, Rev. -0.7k). (Newswires)

Australian Full Time Employment Change (Apr) 32.7k (Prev. -19.9k, Rev. -25.1k)

Australian Unemployment Rate (Apr) 5.6% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.5%)

Australian Participation Rate (Apr) 65.6% vs. Exp. 65.5% (Prev. 65.5%)

New Zealand Economic Forecast 3.14B (Prev. 2.54B)

New Zealand Net Debt Forecast 20.8% (Prev. 21.7%)

New Zealand Budget Balance -1.25B (Prev. -2.65B)

TRADE

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, Commerce Secretary Ross and Trade Representative Lighthizer will be meeting with the Chinese delegation, while there were conflicting reports on whether Trump trade adviser and China-hawk Navarro will be attending. (Newswires)

Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said it is basically impossible to have a NAFTA deal by the 17th and that NAFTA ministers are exploring the possibility of meeting again. Guajardo added that the soft deadline has some margin of flexibility and does not rule out reaching a NAFTA deal from end of May onwards. Elsewhere, US Trade Representative Lighthizer is said to not be optimistic for an imminent NAFTA agreement. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Brazilian Selic Interest Rate 6.50% vs. Exp. 6.25% (Prev. 6.50%); vote was unanimous. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) says additional rate increases may depress inflation expectations and that Fed action which inverts yield curves is a very negative signal. (Newswires)

ECB's Constancio (Dovish) says there must be acceptance the ECB has no excuses not to intervene in the sovereign bond market to deal with acute liquidity stress. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Trump legal adviser Giuliani said Special Counsel Mueller told the Trump team that he will adhere to Justice Department guidance that a sitting president cannot be indicted. (CNN)

There were initial reports from the Telegraph that the UK is to tell EU it is prepared to remain in customs union arrangement beyond 2021. However, this was then dismissed by sources at PM May’s office. (Telegraph/Newswires)

UK PM May says they are considering amendments to the EU withdrawal bill, it is right to take their time on that, and negotiations on a workable backstop arrangement are being negotiated with the EU. (Newswires)

Britain considering continued application of EU's external tariffs for a time-limited period after December 2020 as part of a back stop arrangement in case Brexit deal implementation is delayed. (Newswires)

UK trade body EEF chief stated that “maximum facilitation’ customs plan backed by Boris Johnson and other Brexiteers has major flaws and won’t be ready in time for the end of the transition period in 2020. (FT)

Germany's Merkel says EU is ready to talk about reciprocal reduction of US tariffs if the metals exemption is permanent. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Discounting the SMI (-0.1%) being weighed on by major component underperformance all major European bourses are trading in positive territory for the day with the Euro Stoxx 50 up 0.2%.

In an earnings heavy morning, Altice (+8.1%) Lagardere (+0.2%) and National Grid (+1.6%) posted positive results and are currently trading positive for the day, with AP Moeller-Maersk (-10.3%) Investec (-1.7%) and Royal Mail (-5.9%) coming in under expectations and trading in negative territory.

Pervasive news for the UK gambling sector with the UK cutting the maximum stake in FOBTs to GBP 2.00 has led to gambling names such as William Hill and Paddy Power being initially lower on the announcements that revenues will be impacted negatively.

Ocado (+68.0%) have been boosted on the news that Kroger is set to take a 5% stake in the co., whilst Recordati (+5.5%) have been supported by the news that CVC Capital Partners is holding talks over an EUR 8bln deal for a takeover of the co., despite there being some disagreements over the price of the deal.

FX

DXY

Volatile trade on conflicting drivers as the ongoing rally in US Treasury yields underpins the Greenback and offers protection against global tariff headwinds. The index is meandering between circa 93.100-560, vs yesterday’s marginal new high for the year around 93.640, and also subject to choppy moves on the back of fluctuating fortunes in basket currencies.

GBP/EUR 

The Pound has been buffeted by latest Brexit reports suggesting a customs union back-stop in some shape or form, with an initial boost on paper talk that the UK may stay in the current EU fold until 20121 or longer and then a downturn on denials via a spokesperson for PM May. However, Cable recovered to 1.3500+ and Eur/Gbp back below 0.8750 after subsequent headlines essentially pointing to a halfway house, while Eur/Usd remained leggy above 1.1800 after weakening to a fresh ytd low on Wednesday around 1.1761, and testing the downside again.

CAD/AUD/NZD

Both holding a firmer line vs their US counterpart, the Loonie still getting some support from elevated oil prices and not giving up on a NAFTA deal before the day is out even though the prospects are waning – Usd/Cad currently nearer the bottom of a 1.2795-50 range, above hefty option expiries at 1.2700 (running off today and more for Friday’s NY cut) and well within barriers from 1.2925-1.2625. The Aud saw 2-way price action after a mixed Aussie jobs report overnight and has settled towards the middle of a 0.7505-45 band as some elements of the labour data were encouraging, while cross flows were also bullish as Aud/Nzd rebounded over 1.0900 again. Note, the Kiwi has also struggled above 0.6900 vs the Usd even though the NZ budget balance and forecasts improved overnight.

JPY/CHF

Usd/Jpy a major mover, and largely to the upside as a series of technical levels held ahead of 110.00, including the 55 HMA and 200 DMA. Supply from Japanese exporters and option-related offers at 110.50 have been absorbed on the way to a 110.75 high, and the next bullish objective is a key Fib (110.85), while market contacts note corporate sell orders layered at 10 pip intervals from 110.50 to 111.00. Usd/Chf dull in comparison either side of par, while Eur/Chf has pared some recent losses to regain the 1.1800 handle.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds rebounding firmly into positive territory and back above the 158 level to a new high for the day at 158.39 vs. the 157.73 low, while BTPs succumb to more heavy selling and reverse all and a lot more of their early recovery gains. The Italian 10 year benchmark has been down to 134.19, -94 ticks and taking the cumulative loss to well over two full points in less than two sessions. More concerns about the political situation and potential disruptive influence from the new regime in Rome clearly weighing on sentiment and spreading to other peripheral bonds. Prior to all this, a fleeting attempt to hold above 158.00 off the Eurex open only seemed to exacerbate the extent and speed of the subsequent fall the 10 year German bond found some underlying bids/support.

Meanwhile, conflicting reports about an offer to stay in the EU customs union for another 3 years if not longer prompted a shallow recovery in UK debt and STIR futures, which remain under considerable pressure in keeping with the bearish tone elsewhere. In fact, Gilts are now slipping to new lows (121.07 vs 121.11 previously and -48 ticks on the day) having gapped down to 121.27 from yesterday’s 121.55 Liffe close initially and only recovering to opening levels as a PM May spokesperson denied that any extended stay in the bloc’s customs union is under consideration, and instead suggested a halfway alternative. Gilts then got a safe heaven boost with bunds to trade as high as 121.41 before fading.

Turning to US Treasuries, futures have climbed off overnight lows but the curve remains steeper as 10 and 30 year yields hit fresh cyclical/multi-year peaks around 3.12% and 3.25% respectively. Some decent data/surveys to take on board later including weekly claims, Philly Fed and the leading index, along with more Fed speak.

COMMODITIES

Oil is trading marginally higher today with Brent breaching USD 80/bbl, supported the prospect of a sharp drop in Iranian crude supply. There has been little oil news flow following the larger than expected DoE crude inventory drawdown. Barclays raised their Brent oil assumptions to USD 73/bbl in 2018 and USD 70/bbl in 2019, following suit from other analysts. Yesterday, Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh stated Iran will be doing its best to maintain production and continue exports, while he also commented that oil prices at USD 60-65/bbl are 'logical' and the US wants to see high prices to boost shale production. Elsewhere, gold and copper trade lower on the day as the yellow and red metal track the current risk tone.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
UK gambling names – UK government reduced the maximum stake on B2 gaming machines (FOBTs) from GBP 100 to GBP 2. Maintaining the status quo on stakes, prizes and allocations for all other gaming machines. (Newswires)

William HIll (WMH LN) - The co's prelim. estimates say that due to the T stake limit C900 William Hill shops could become loss making with a reduction in total gaming net revenue of 35-45% and operating profit cut by GBP 70-100mln, despite this they maintain their current intentions to pay out ~50% of underlying earnings. (Newswires)

AP Moller - Maersk (MAERSKB DC) – Q1 revenue USD 9.253bln vs. Exp. USD 8.755bln, EBITDA USD 669mln vs. Exp. USD 852mln, currently implementing short term initiatives to improve profitability and reiterate FY guidance. (Newswires)

Investec (INVP LN) – FY net interest income GBP 760.4mln vs. prev. GBP 679.9mln, profit before tax GBP 637.5mln vs. prev. GBP 637.4mln, diluted EPS 47.4 pence/share vs. prev. 46.3pence/share. (Newswires)

EX-DIVS: HSBC (HSBA LN), Intertek Group (ITRK LN), Tesco (TSCO LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 6.77 points off the FTSE 100

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – FY revenue GBP 10.172bln vs. Prev. GBP 9.776bln. FY adjusted operating profit before transformation costs GBP 694mln, +1% on underlying basis. Board is recommending a final dividend of GBP 0.163/shr, +4%. Maintains outlook for addressed letter volume declines of 4%-6% PA (excluding election mailing) over the medium term. Transformation costs expected to be at the upper end of the forecast GBP 130mln-150mln range in 2018/19. (Newswires)

Experian (EXPN LN) – FY revenue USD 4.662bln vs. Prev. USD 4.335bln. FY profit before tax USD 0.994bln vs. Prev. USD 1.071bln. Total dividends +8% to USD 0.4475/shr. (Newswires)  

Ocado (OCDO LN) – Co. announces Kroger is to take up to a 5% stake in the Co. (Newswires)

National Grid (NG/ LN) – FY pre tax profit GBP 2.708bln vs. Exp. GBP 2.68bln, underlying operating profit +4% to GBP 3.5bln vs. Exp. GBP 3.55bln, final dividend 30.44 pence/share, expects growth at top end of 5-7% range on medium term and 7% in near term. (Newswires)

3I Group (III LN) – Total return of GBP 1.425bln or 24% on opening shareholders funds, NAV per share of GBP 7.24 vs. prev. GBP 6.04. total dividend 30 pence/share, say they enter FY 2019 with good momentum. (Newswires)

British Land (BLND LN) – FY underlying profit -2.6% at GBP 380mln following GBP 1.5bln net sales of income producing assets, dividends up 8.9% to 7.52 pence/share, expect demand for their space to remain firm. (Newswires)

Moneysupermarket.com Group (MONY LN) – CFO has stepped down from the co. (Newswires)

Foxtons (FOXT LN) – Q1 revenue GBP 24.5mln vs. prev. GBP 28.7mln, conditions in London market remain challenging with sales volumes lower than prev. year, performance in lettings was impacted by a slow start to January and timing of Easter, had a negative effect on revenue. (Newswires)

Lagardere (MMB FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 1.555bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.51bln, recurring EBIT is expected to remain stable vs. 2017 at constant FX rates. (Newswires)

RTL (RTL BB) – Q1 revenue +0.8% to EUR 1.42bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.44bln. Q1 EBITDA -1.9% to EUR 259mln vs. Exp. EUR 268mln. Q1 EPS EUR 0.72 vs. Exp. EUR 0.91. Co. maintains guidance. (Newswires)

Paddy Power Betfair (PPB LN) - Co. estimate new stake limit will lead to a 33-43% decrease in total machine gaming revenue, in 2017 impact would have equated to GBP 35-46mln revenue impact. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
17th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued as the initial tailwind from a rebound in US stocks gradually waned after trade protectionism concerns were stoked overnight. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) both opened higher as they took cue from Wall St where markets shrugged off rising Treasury yields and US data including Industrial Production provided some encouragement. However, Australian stocks then retreated amid heavy losses in the Industrials sector and a deterioration in both Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) in which the latter wiped out gains of over 1%. This was due to trade concerns after China’s Mofcom released its statement on previously announced tariffs in which it is to levy reciprocal taxes on some US products and halt tariff concessions on imports of US fruit and pork, which doesn’t bode well ahead of today’s US-China trade talks. Furthermore, Japan was also said to inform the WTO regarding its own trade response and that it is ready to retaliate against US tariff actions, although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later downplayed it and stated that nothing yet has been decided. Conversely, not all was not all was gloomy in the region as Tencent outperformed in Hong Kong with gains nearly 5% after it posted an over 60% increase in Q1 net. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as yields played catch up to their US counterparts, while a 5yr JGB auction also failed to support as the b/c and accepted prices slipped from prior.

FTSE

UK gambling names – UK cuts maximum stake in FOBTs to GBP 2 as expected. (Newswires)

BHP (BLT LN) – Co. is facing legal action from shareholders who claim the Co. mislead them over safety measures at a dam in Brazil which broke and killed 19 people, causing the country’s worst environmental disaster. (The Independent)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Mothercare (MTC LN) – The co. will announce a rescue plan tomorrow including the closure of 50 shops in the UK and rehiring its former chief executive Mark Newton-Jones. (Sky News)

BROKER MOVES

NATIONAL EXPRESS (NEX LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY)/ Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – The cos. plan to make a EUR 3.2bln payment to the government. (Handelsblatt)

Merck (MRK GY) – The co.’s two oncology drugs have shown early signs of promise in some lung cancer patients, possibly helping the co. efforts to find drug-industry partners to share development costs. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Metro (B4B GY) – The co.’s Chief executive has bought ~ EUR 1mln worth of shares in the co. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

TLG IMMOBILIEN (TLG GY) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

HEIDELBERGCEMENT (HEI GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT KEPLER CHEUVREUX

CAC

Total (FP FP) - Iran’s oil minister said the co. will not pay penalty if is to exit the gas contract, but cannot hold the invested amount until the project is completed. (Newswires)

Vivendi (VIV FP) – The co.’s board is considering the future of the Universal Music Group in an upcoming board meeting, taking place on Thursday, with an IPO or sale to another company some of the possible options. (Newswires)

Bouygues (EN FP) – Q1 revenue EUR 6.836bln vs. prev. EUR 6.837bln, current operating loss EUR 111mln vs. prev. loss of EUR 75mln, reiterates expectation to improve profitability gradually in 2018, Q1 not indicative of FY performance. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

ADP (ADP FP) – 1.2% less passengers welcomed vs. April 2017 at 8.7mln , traffic within France -5.7%, international traffic excluding Europe +0.6%, European traffic excluding France -1.2%. (Newswires)

Suez (SEV FP) – Q1 revenue +1.7% on organic basis to EUR 4.06bln. Q1 EBITDA +3.4% to EUR 635mln, EBIT +2.8% to EUR 289mln. Co. confirms 2018 earnings guidance. (Newswires)

Suez (SEV FP)/Veolia (VIE FP) – JV with the Co.’s has been awarded a EUR 275mln contract to supply drinking water in Bangladesh. (Newswires)

Icade (ICAD FP) – The co. and ANF Immobilier have approved the final terms of a merger. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equities failed to hold on to opening gains as trade concerns gripped sentiment ahead of China-US trade talks
content:
Asian equities failed to hold on to opening gains as trade concerns gripped sentiment ahead of China-US trade talks

In FX, DXY is softer and underpinning its peers with GBP/USD also supported by reports that the UK is to tell the EU it is prepared to remain in the customs union arrangement beyond 2021

Looking ahead, highlights include US weekly jobs, Philly Fed, ECB’s Constancio, Fed’s Kashkari, Kaplan and BoE’s Haldane

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly subdued as the initial tailwind from a rebound in US stocks gradually waned after trade protectionism concerns were stoked overnight. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) both opened higher as they took cue from Wall St where markets shrugged off rising Treasury yields and US data including Industrial Production provided some encouragement. However, Australian stocks then retreated amid heavy losses in the Industrials sector and a deterioration in both Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) in which the latter wiped out gains of over 1%. This was due to trade concerns after China’s Mofcom released its statement on previously announced tariffs in which it is to levy reciprocal taxes on some US products and halt tariff concessions on imports of US fruit and pork, which doesn’t bode well ahead of today’s US-China trade talks. Furthermore, Japan was also said to inform the WTO regarding its own trade response and that it is ready to retaliate against US tariff actions, although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later downplayed it and stated that nothing yet has been decided. Conversely, not all was not all was gloomy in the region as Tencent outperformed in Hong Kong with gains nearly 5% after it posted an over 60% increase in Q1 net. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as yields played catch up to their US counterparts, while a 5yr JGB auction also failed to support as the b/c and accepted prices slipped from prior.

China is to levy reciprocal tax on some US products and will stop tariff concessions on imports of US fruits and pork, according to statement posted by China Mofcom regarding previously announced tariffs, although Mofcom also reiterated China doesn't want to see trade tensions with US to escalate. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day and CNY 20bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3679 (Prev. 6.3745).

There were reports that Japan is said to inform WTO regarding retaliatory steps related to US tariffs and will also notify WTO it is prepared to retaliate against US tariff actions. However, Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later answered a question on retaliatory measures on US tariffs, in which he stated Japan is considering steps under WTO framework but nothing has been decided yet. (Newswires)

Japanese Machinery Orders (Mar) M/M -3.9% vs. Exp. -3.0% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)
Japanese Machinery Orders (Mar) Y/Y -2.4% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 2.4%)


UK/EU

UK is to tell EU it is prepared to remain in customs union arrangement beyond 2021. (Telegraph)

UK trade body EEF chief stated that “maximum facilitation’ customs plan backed by Boris Johnson and other Brexiteers has major flaws and won’t be ready in time for the end of the transition period in 2020. (FT)

Italy's M5S and the League have completed the joint policy programme and passed on the document to leaders for its approval, although it is not due to be officially released until the weekend. Furthermore, the Five Star and League government contract is said not to include a Euro exit option. (Newswires)
 

FX

The DXY is weaker on a continuation of the prior day’s pullback and on the Chinese sabre-rattling ahead of trade talks. This underpinned its major counterparts with GBP/USD also finding solace on reports that the UK is to tell the EU it is prepared to remain in the customs union arrangement beyond 2021. Elsewhere. AUD/USD saw a bout of indecision on mixed jobs data as Employment Change topped estimates and the Unemployment Rate unexpectedly rose. However, AUD eventually extended on gains as the rise in unemployment coincided with an increase in the Participation Rate and as the data ultimately showed better quality of growth as it was solely fuelled by Full-Time jobs. NZD/USD also mirrored gains after the New Zealand budget showed forecasts for a larger surplus in the near term and that GDP guidance was raised to 3.8% from 3.4% for 2018/19.

Australian Employment Change (Apr) 22.6k vs. Exp. 20.0k (Prev. 4.9k, Rev. -0.7k). (Newswires)
Australian Full Time Employment Change (Apr) 32.7k (Prev. -19.9k, Rev. -25.1k)
Australian Unemployment Rate (Apr) 5.6% vs. Exp. 5.5% (Prev. 5.5%)
Australian Participation Rate (Apr) 65.6% vs. Exp. 65.5% (Prev. 65.5%)

Brazilian Selic Interest Rate 6.50% vs. Exp. 6.25% (Prev. 6.50%); vote was unanimous. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities saw mild support overnight alongside the backdrop of a softer greenback with WTI crude futures making further headway towards the USD 72.00/bbl after prices were lifted during US trade by a larger than expected DoE crude inventory drawdown. Elsewhere, gold and copper were also marginally positive but with upside contained on lingering prospects of 4 Fed hike this year and by a subdued risk tone, respectively.

Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh stated Iran will be doing its best to maintain production and continue exports, while he also commented that oil prices at USD 60-65/bbl are 'logical' and the US wants to see high prices to boost shale production. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said 'we'll have to see' if the North Korea summit is still on and will insist on the denuclearisation of North Korea, while US National Security Adviser Bolton said that the Trump-Kim summit should still happen even though North Korea is threatening to back out. (Fox News)

Paris continues to work with Iran to expand the agreement by adding its missile programme and actions in the region to the deal whilst preserving original JCPOA, according to a French ambassador speaking to Russia. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasuries ended the day pretty much unchanged, despite decent volumes and a busy day in the European fixed income complex, where Italian BTPs tumbled amid political uncertainty whilst German bunds acted as a safe haven alternative. Treasury yields were higher by less than 1bps, with the exception of the 10yr yield which was higher by just about 1bps, consolidating yesterday’s gains above the 3% level. Heading towards settlement, 2s10s widened by c.1bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 2 ticks lower at 118-17+.

Trump legal adviser Giuliani said Special Counsel Mueller told the Trump team that he will adhere to Justice Department guidance that a sitting president cannot be indicted. (CNN)

Fed's Bullard (non-voter, dove) said US is close to neutral rate, while he also commented that there is no yield curve inversion danger just now and that it has a nice slope. Bullard later added that additional rate increases may depress inflation expectations and that Fed action which inverts yield curves is a very negative signal. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, Commerce Secretary Ross and Trade Representative Lighthizer will be meeting with the Chinese delegation, while there were conflicting reports on whether Trump trade adviser and China-hawk Navarro will be attending. (Newswires)

US House Ways and Means Committee Chair Brady said Chinese Vice-Premier Liu wants to increase Chinese demand for US products and that he does see problems in trade relations, although he added that Liu is said to be optimistic about trade talks. (Newswires)

Mexican Economy Minister Guajardo said it is basically impossible to have a NAFTA deal by the 17th and that NAFTA ministers are exploring the possibility of meeting again. Guajardo added that the soft deadline has some margin of flexibility and does not rule out reaching a NAFTA deal from end of May onwards. Elsewhere, US Trade Representative Lighthizer is said to not be optimistic for an imminent NAFTA agreement. (Newswires)

content:
Asia equity markets are mostly subdued as the initial tailwind from a rebound in US stocks gradually waned after trade protectionism concerns were stoked. ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) both opened higher as they took cue from Wall St where markets shrugged off rising Treasury yields and after US data including Industrial Production provided some encouragement. However, Australian stocks then retreated amid heavy losses in the Industrials sector and a deterioration in both Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) in which the latter all but wiped out gains of over 1%. This was due to trade tensions after China’s Mofcom released its statement on previously announced tariffs in which it is to levy reciprocal taxes on some US products and halt tariff concessions on imports of US fruit and pork, which likely won’t bode well ahead of today’s US-China trade talks. Furthermore, Japan was also said to inform the WTO regarding its own trade response and that it is ready to retaliate against US tariff actions, although Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga later downplayed it and stated that nothing yet has been decided.

In FX markets, the DXY is weaker on a continuation of the prior day’s pullback and on the Chinese sabre-rattling ahead of trade talks. This has underpinned its major counterparts with GBP/USD also finding solace on reports that the UK is to tell the EU it is prepared to remain in customs union arrangement beyond 2021. Elsewhere. AUD/USD saw a bout of indecision on mixed jobs data as Employment Change topped estimates but the Unemployment Rate unexpectedly rose. However, AUD eventually extended on gains as the rise in unemployment coincided with an increase in the Participation Rate and as the data ultimately showed better quality of growth and was solely fuelled by Full-Time jobs, while NZD/USD also mirrored gains after the New Zealand budget forecast a larger surplus in the near term and also raised GDP guidance to 3.8% from 3.4% for 2018/19.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lacklustre amid an indecisive tone in stocks and with participants awaiting a 5yr auction later today.
